snippet: With often cheaper imports unavailable, some agricultural activists hope to see a boost in local farming, but for consumers the self-imposed sanctions have so far served mostly to raise food prices.
abstract: Boris Akimov, Russian founder of organic farm cooperative LavkaLavka, hopes ban on food imports from the West will boost Russia's fledgling farm-to-table movement; Akimov found himself flooded with requests from grocery chains after Pres Vladimir Putin imposed ban in retaliation for Western sanctions.

byline.contributor: Nikolay Khalip and Alexandra Odynova contributed reporting.

lead_paragraph: With often cheaper imports unavailable, some agricultural activists hope to see a boost in local farming, but for consumers the self-imposed sanctions have so far served mostly to raise food prices.

headline.main: Organic Farms Become a Winner in Putin’s Feud With the West
headline.print_headline: Organic Farms Become a Winner in Putin’s Feud With the West
